case_name: President of the Municipal Board, Pilkhuwa v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1961. Appeal

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 24, 1961 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 846 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 24, 1961, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 846 of 1961. C. Setalvad

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition praying for mandamus directing State of Uttar Pradesh and District Magistrate Meerut not to give effect to resolution dated February 6, 1961 and to quash proceedings of that day.

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Allahabad dismissing a writ petition filed by the appellant praying for the issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus directing the State of Uttar Pradesh and the District Magistrate, Meerut, number to give effect to the

facts.text: Appellant was President of Municipal Board Pilkhuwa in January-February 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the President of the Municipal Board, Pilkhuwa, in January-February, 1959. On January 4, 1959, a written numberice of the intention to

facts.text: On January 4, 1959, written notice of intention to make motion of no-confidence signed by nine members including Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta delivered to District Magistrate Meerut pursuant to sub-s.2 of s.87-A of U.P. Municipalities Act 1916.

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1959, a written numberice of the intention to make a motion of numberconfidence in the President signed by nine members of the Board, including Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta, was delivered to the District Magistrate, Meerut, in Pursuance of sub-s.  2  of s.87-A of the U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916  U.P. Act II of 19 16 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: District Magistrate Meerut convened meeting of the Board on February 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Meerut, duly companyvened a meeting of the Board on February 6, 1961. The appellant moved writ petition No. 367 of 1961 in the High Court on February 2, 1961,

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition No. 367 of 1961 on February 2, 1961 questioning validity of notice, dismissed in limine same day as premature.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved writ petition No. 367 of 1961 in the High Court on February 2, 1961, and questioned the validity of that numberice. That petition was dismissed in limine on the same day. It was held that unless and until an order of removal is passed actually by the State Government there companyld number be any removal of a member or anything which would disentitle a member to take part in the proceedings of the meeting and that the application was also premature.

facts.text: Meeting of Board took place on February 6, 1961 presided by Mr. Agarwala Munsif Meerut; all ten members present voted for no-confidence motion; Munsif declared motion carried.

anchor.surface_text: The meeting of the Board took place on February 6, 1961. Mr. Agarwala, Munsif, Meerut, presided over the meeting all the ten members who were present, voted for the motion of numberconfidence and the Munsif declared the motion to, have been carried. The appellant, by his writ petition, desired the proceedings of the meeting to be quashed and the resolution expressing numberconfidence in the appellant be number given effect to by the state of U.P. an-. the District Magistrate.

facts.text: Ram Nath, Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad incurred disqualification under s.13-D(g) prior to January 4, 1961 as in arrears of municipal tax and dues excess of one year's demand.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta who had signed the numberice and also Raghunandan I?,, Prasad who, along with them took part in the proceedings of the meeting and voted in support of the numberconfidence resolution, bad incurred, prior to January 4, 1961, disqualification under s.13-D  g  of the Act inasmuch as they were in arrears in the payment of municipal tax and other dues in excess of one years demand to which s. 166 of the Act applied.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held Ram Nath in arrears of house tax on February 6, 1961; Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad not in arrears of Tehbazari tax 1959-60 and house tax respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that Ram Nath had been proved to be in arrears in payment of house tax on February 6, 196 1, and that Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad were number in arrears in payment of the Tehbzarai tax for the year 1959-60 and house tax respectively.

facts.text: Total number of members of the Board is seventeen.

facts.text: Nine members signed the notice of no-confidence.

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1959, a written numberice of the intention to make a motion of numberconfidence in the President signed by nine members of the Board, including Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta, was delivered to the District Magistrate, Meerut, in Pursuance of sub-s.  2  of s.87-A of the U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916  U.P. Act II of 19 16 , hereinafter called the Act. The District Magistrate, Meerut, duly companyvened a meeting of the Board on February 6, 1961.

facts.text: Ten members present at meeting on February 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The meeting of the Board took place on February 6, 1961. Mr. Agarwala, Munsif, Meerut, presided over the meeting all the ten members who were present, voted for the motion of numberconfidence and the Munsif declared the motion to, have been carried.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: C. Setalvad Attorney-General for India and J.P. Goyal for the appellant. B. Agarwala and C. P. Lal, for respondents Nos. 1 and 2. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, R. K. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment of the, High Court of Allahabad dismissing a writ petition filed by the appellant

facts.text: High Court held motion of no-confidence valid as passed by vote of nine members constituting majority of more than half total 17 members.

anchor.surface_text: Holding that the motion of numberconfidence was valid as it had been passed by the vote of nine members who companystituted the majority of more than half the total number of members of the Board, that being seventeen,

facts.text: Kesho Ram Gupta deposited amount under protest on February 9, 1961 which Board resolved to refund.

anchor.surface_text: Kesho Ram Gupta was also a disqualified member of the Board and the resolution of the Board dated February 6, 1961, holding that numberTehbazari tax was due from Kesho Ram Gupta and that the amount deposited by him under protest on February 9, 1961, be refunded., was ultra vires the power of the Board

facts.text: Supreme Court holds member incurring disqualification under s.13-D(g) does not cease to be member or lose right to act until suspended or removed under s.40.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that a member of the Municipal Board does number automatically companye under suspension or lose his right to take part in the proceedings of the board or perform the duties of a member or cease to be a member of the board merely on his incurring any of the disqualifications mentioned in a. 13-D.

facts.text: Proceedings of meeting and resolution of February 6, 1961 are valid.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the proceedings of, and the resolution passed at the meeting of February 6, 1961, are valid and that the order of the High Court dismissing the appellants writ petition is companyrect, though for different reasons.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents conceded that order on writ No. 397 of 1961 does not operate as res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the respondents companyceded that the order dismissing writ No., 397 of 1961 companyld number operate as res judicata in these ,proceedings on the question whether the numberice of numberconfidence was a valid numberice or number.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, R. K. Garg, S. Agarwala, D. P. Singh and M. K. Ramamurthi, for respondents Nos. 3 to 13. 1961. September 20. facts.text: High Court did not consider validity of notice on merits due to res judicata from writ No. 397 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges did number companysider the validity of the numberice on merits as they were of opinion that the order on writ petition No. 397 of 1961 operated as res judicata, though in view of their opinion the numberice of motion of numberconfidence would have been invalid if the name of Ram Nath be excluded from the signatories as in that case the number would be eight and so one short of the number required by the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 87-A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 40 deals with the removal of members and empowers the State Government  1  1953 S.C.R. 1144. in the case of a city or the Prescribed Authority in any other case, to remove a member of the board on any of the grounds mentioned in cls.  a  to  f  of sub-s.  1 . The ground for removal mentioned in cl.  b  is that a member has incurred any of the disqualifications mentioned in Bs. 12-D and 13-D. Sub-sections  3 ,  4  and  5  of s. 40 read The State Government may remove from the board a member who in its opinion has so flagrantly abused in any manner his position as a member of the board as to render his companytinuance as a member detrimental to the public interest Provided that when either the State Government or the Prescribed Authority, as the case may be, proposes to take action under the foregoing provisions of this section, an opportunity of explanation shall be given to the member companycerned, and when such action is taken the reasons therefore shall be placed on record. The State Government may place under suspension a member, against whom proceeding under sub-sections  3 and  4  has been companymenced, until the companyclusion of the enquiry and any member who has been so suspended shall number so long as the order of suspension companytinues to remain in force, be entitled to take part in any proceedings of the board or otherwise perform the duties of a member.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for removal and suspension of members incurring disqualification; implies member retains rights absent such order

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: and  5  of s. 40 read The State Government may remove from the board a member who in its opinion has so flagrantly abused in any manner his position

Saka Venkata Subba Rao  1  in companynection with the interpretation of Art. 191, whose relevant provision is is person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State It was observed at page 1157 Article 191, which lays down the same set of disqualifications for election as well as for companytinuing as a member, and article 193 which prescribes the penalty for sitting and voting when disqualified, are naturally phrased in terms wide enough to companyer both preexisting and supervening disqualifications.

issues.text: Whether the order dismissing writ petition No. 397 of 1961 operates as res judicata on the validity of the no-confidence notice?

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges did not consider the validity of the notice on merits as they were of opinion that the order on writ petition No. 397 of 1961 operated as res judicata, though in view of their opinion the notice of motion of no confidence would have been invalid if the name of Ram Nath be excluded from the signatories as in that case the number would be eight and so one short of the number required by the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 87-A of the Act. The learned counsel for the respondents conceded that the order dismissing writ No., 397 of 1961 could not operate as res judicata in these ,proceedings on the question whether the notice of no confidence was a valid notice or not.

issues.text: Whether a member of the Municipal Board who incurs disqualification under s.13-D ceases to be a member or loses the right to act as a member until removal under s.40?

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that a member of the Municipal Board does not automatically come under suspension or lose his right to take part in the proceedings of the board or perform the duties of a member or cease to be a member of the board merely on his incurring any of the disqualifications mentioned in s. 13-D.

issues.text: Whether the resolution of the Board dated February 6, 1961 holding no Tehbazari tax due from Kesho Ram Gupta and refunding deposit was ultra vires?

anchor.surface_text: Kesho Ram Gupta was also a disqualified member of the Board and the resolution of the Board dated February 6, 1961, holding that no Tehbazari tax was due from Kesho Ram Gupta and that the amount deposited by him under protest on February 9, 1961, be refunded., was ultra vires the power of the Board

issues.text: Whether the no-confidence notice under s.87-A(2) and meeting proceedings were invalid due to signatures and votes by disqualified members Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta?

anchor.surface_text: On January 4, 1959, a written notice of the intention to make a motion of no confidence in the President signed by nine members of the Board, including Ram Nath and Kesho Ram Gupta, was delivered to the District Magistrate, Meerut, in Pursuance of sub-s.  2  of s.87-A of the U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916  U.P. Act II of 19 16 , hereinafter called the Act. ...The learned Judges did not consider the validity of the notice on merits as they were of opinion that the order on writ petition No. 397 of 1961 operated as res judicata, though in view of their opinion the notice of motion of no confidence would have been invalid if the name of Ram Nath be excluded from the signatories as in that case the number would be eight and so one short of the number required by the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 87-A of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the no-confidence meeting proceedings were vitiated by disqualified member's participation and not saved by s.113(2)?

arguments.claim: A member of the Municipal Board, on incurring a disqualification under s. 13-D, ceases to be a member of the Board so long as the disqualification exists and therefore he cannot act as a member of the Board for any purpose.

anchor.surface_text: A member of the Municipal Board, on incurring a disqualification under s. 13-D, ceases to be a member of the Board so long as the disqualification exists and therefore he cannot act as a member of the Board for any purpose.

arguments.court_reasoning: No provision for automatic cessation or suspension; inferred from s.40 that member retains rights until removed or suspended.

arguments.claim: A member does not cease to be a member on incurring disqualification under s.13-D(g), but becomes disqualified to exercise office and act as member; right to act suspended during disqualification unless removed under s.40.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that Ram Nath had been proved to be in arrears in payment of house tax on February 6, 196 1, and that Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad were number in arrears in payment of the Tehbzarai tax for the year 1959-60 and house tax respectively. It held that a member of the Board did number cease to be a member on his mourning the disqualification under s.13-D g  and that he became disqualified merely to exercise office and to act as a member. The I-earned Judges observed During the companytinuance of the dis- qualification the persons right to act as a member falls into a state of suspension.

arguments.claim: Member incurring disqualification under s.13-D does not automatically cease to be member, suspend, or lose right to act; retains rights until suspended or removed under s.40.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that a member of the Municipal Board does number automatically companye under suspension or lose his right to take part in the proceedings of the board or perform the duties of a member or cease to be a member of the board merely on his incurring any of the disqualifications mentioned in a. 13-D.

arguments.claim: Proceedings vitiated by disqualified Ram Nath's participation and not saved by s.113(2) as s.87-A meeting not ordinary Board meeting.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings of the meeting were vitiated even if Ram Nath alone, who was a disqualified member, had taken part in the meeting and were number saved by the provisions of sub-s.  2  of a. 113, as the meeting held in pursuance of the provisions of s. 87-A of the Act is number a meeting of the Board to which the provisions of sub-s.  2  of s. 113 can apply.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary as disqualification does not affect rights.

holdings.text: The order dismissing writ petition No. 397 of 1961 could not operate as res judicata in these proceedings on the question whether the notice of no confidence was a valid notice or not.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondents conceded that the order dismissing writ No., 397 of 1961 could not operate as res judicata in these ,proceedings on the question whether the notice of no confidence was a valid notice or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted respondents' concession; prior dismissal was premature and not on merits, allowing consideration of notice validity on merits.

holdings.text: A member of the Municipal Board does not automatically come under suspension or lose his right to take part in the proceedings of the board or perform the duties of a member or cease to be a member of the board merely on his incurring any of the disqualifications mentioned in s. 13-D.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that a member of the Municipal Board does not automatically come under suspension or lose his right to take part in the proceedings of the board or perform the duties of a member or cease to be a member of the board merely on his incurring any of the disqualifications mentioned in s. 13-D.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.13-D lacks provision for automatic suspension or cessation; s.40 requires proceedings for removal/suspension, implying retention of rights until order; s.13-D covers supervening disqualifications per precedent on Art.191; avoids uncertainty in board functioning.

holdings.text: Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad ... were not incompetent to exercise their rights as members of the board and could therefore validly sign the notice of motion of no confidence and take part in the proceedings of the meeting held in pursuance of the provisions of s. 87-A of the Act on February 6, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Kesho Ram Gupta and Raghunandan Prasad had incurred the disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D of the Act, they were not incompetent to exercise their rights as members of the board and could therefore validly sign the notice., of motion of no confidence and take part in the proceedings of the meeting held in pursuance of the provisions of s. 87-A of the Act on February 6, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of holding on retention of membership rights despite disqualification under s.13-D.

holdings.text: The proceedings of, and the resolution passed at the meeting of February 6, 1961, are valid and ... the order of the High Court dismissing the appellant's writ petition is correct, though for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the proceedings of, and the resolution passed at the meeting of February 6, 1961, are valid and that the order of the High Court dismissing the appellants writ petition is correct, though for different reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from validity of signatures and participation by disqualified members; affirms High Court dismissal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Election Commission, India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao  1  1953 S.C.R. 1144.

precedents.case_name: Election Commission of India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: The expression 'for being chosen as, and for being' in Article 191 covers both pre-existing and supervening disqualifications for continuing as a member.
precedents.cited_holding: Article 191, which lays down the same set of disqualifications for election as well as for continuing as a member, and article 193 which prescribes the penalty for sitting and voting when disqualified, are naturally phrased in terms wide enough to cover both preexisting and supervening disqualifications.
